Automated generation of engineering rationale, knowledge and intent representations during the product life cycle
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • SI: Manufacturing and Construction
  • Published: 03 August 2011

Automated generation of engineering rationale, knowledge and intent representations during the product life cycle

  • Raymond C. W. Sung1,
  • James M. Ritchie1,
  • Theodore Lim1 &
  • Zoe Kosmadoudi1 

Virtual Reality volume 16, pages69–85(2012)Cite this article

  • 419 Accesses

  • 13 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

One of the biggest challenges in engineering design and manufacturing environments is the effective capture of and decoding of tacit knowledge. Fundamental to Life Cycle Engineering is the capture of engineering information and knowledge created at all stages of the product development process, from conceptual design through to product support and disposal. Consider this—the amount of vital information and knowledge lost when key design personnel retire—hence the need to capture meta-cognitive task-related strategies, particularly to support knowledge reuse and training. Many methods have been tried and tested with the successful few found to be very time consuming and expensive to implement and carry out; consequently, there is a need to investigate alternative paradigms for knowledge and information capture. This paper reports on a current industrial case study on knowledge capture methods employed by industrial partners in the design and manufacture of a variety of electro-mechanical products. The results suggest the need for new kinds and forms of knowledge capture methods and representation, particularly those associated with individual design engineering tasks. Following the findings, the paper presents a knowledge capture methodology for automatic real-time logging, capture and post-processing of design data from a virtual reality design system. Task-based design experiments were carried out with industrial partners to demonstrate the effective, unobtrusive and automatic capture and representation of various forms of design knowledge and information. Qualitative and quantitative evaluation of knowledge representations were also performed to determine which method was most effective at conveying design knowledge and information for other engineers.

Introduction

In today’s competitive business environment, knowledge and its associated management are seen as a key asset for any company. This is due to the complex nature of interactions that take place within modern commerce, the leaner nature of companies and the way they operate, the sheer volume and nature of data and information with which people are now dealing and the need for reusable, accessible and understandable knowledge formats to aid product and process development. As stated by Goodman (2005): “Organizations that embrace knowledge capture and knowledge management can be more effective at avoiding technical, cost and schedule risks over the life of a program. They also embrace a culture that values theoretical understanding, intellectual curiosity and performance investigation, which enables information technology to be leveraged in an efficient manner to address the knowledge capture and management problem”.

In the context of this research work, this is particularly important when related to engineering knowledge.

Knowledge must be considered different from information or data. Data can be considered as a pre-information state, usually unorganised, unlinked and independent collections of facts, measurements, notes, results, etc., that represent pre-processed outputs from a wide range of activities. Information can be categorised as formal or informal contextualised data, facts or instructions; providing a specific context and measure along with a structure or focus such that knowledge can be inferred from it. Typical forms can be pictorial, textual or verbal (Hicks et al. 2002).

A great deal of debate exists on what defines knowledge and what forms it can take. Sainter et al. (2000) define knowledge as: “…the experience, concepts, values, beliefs and ways of working that can be shared and communicated”. As mentioned by Dalkir (2005, p 36), this includes information that is successfully interpreted by experts which can then be considered as knowledge after subsequent analysis and use. Davenport and Prusak (1997) highlighted the tacit nature of knowledge in that information is most valued precisely because “…somebody has given the information context, meaning, a particular interpretation; somebody has reflected on the knowledge, added their own wisdom to it and considered its larger implications”. Therefore, this work will focus on interpretation and validation by generating knowledge formats and validating them via feedback from expert users. Knowledge tends to take two forms, namely explicit or external and tacit or internal and one of the key challenges of capturing tacit knowledge and turning it into explicit knowledge is to do this quickly, effectively, consistently and regularly throughout any business process. Sherwood and Covin (Sherwood and Covin 2008) refer to explicit knowledge as codified knowledge and tacit knowledge as non-codified knowledge.

In an engineering context, there are significant problems associated with current knowledge capture methods; particularly with regard to cost and time, there is a considerable overhead on engineers in both of these areas and yet it is a vital component in knowledge management (Coombs and Hull 1998). Automating parts of this process could potentially reduce the cost and time overhead traditionally associated with companies requiring the acquisition of such data (Grossman and Bates 2008).

For example, CETIM—an industrial technical centre that represents 7,800 French mechanical industry companies—performed a survey on digital and collaborative engineering for the mechanical engineering sector and discovered that 5% of SMEs use PLM systems to manage their technical data (Bernard et al. 2009), even though more than 70% of these companies appreciate the importance of knowledge reuse and sharing. The main reason given for this is the lack of time and investment in knowledge capture methods within the companies.

An article in CIO Magazine estimated that “…worldwide spending for KM services, including consulting, implementation, operations, support and training, will grow from $776 million in 1998 to $10 billion by 2004”; highlighting the considerable need for investment in this area (Desroches 2007). However, much of this anticipated cost is associated with the time-consuming methods used at that time for knowledge capture.

One key reason for the considerable overhead associated with the knowledge gathering is that the construction of knowledge bases is primarily done by hand (Lockwood 2009). This is time consuming, expensive and can lead to knowledge that is overly tailored to a specific domain or problem. For example, the Cyc knowledge base (Lenat 1995), the largest effort at a common sense knowledge base, has been in development since 1984 at an estimated cost of at least $50 million and over 600 man-years of effort (2002); today it has around 3 million rules of thumb plus around 300,000 terms or concepts but still falls short of human-like common sense knowledge and lacks a means of easily accessing that knowledge.

There is a plethora of traditional methods for capturing knowledge through conducting interviews and questionnaires (Bolisani and Scarso 1999; Henriksen 2001; Kwong and Lee 2009; McAdam et al. 2008; Mulder and Whiteley 2007) or carrying out post-project reviews (Koners and Goffin 2007); however, these methods require a lot of manual work. This tends to deter users from capturing their own knowledge because it would be too laborious a task to do so (Sanderson 2001). The type of knowledge captured in this research can be defined as tacit; this makes it more difficult to record and codify in comparison with explicit knowledge (Cusumano and Nobeoka 1998; Nightingale 1998; Philbin 2008; Sherwood and Covin 2008). The codification process can also be costly to a company (Schulz and Lloyd 2001), but if this step can be automated, as proposed in this paper, then the associated costs will be substantially reduced.

Another benefit of capturing this knowledge would be when an engineer leaves a company, the knowledge that would traditionally be lost will now still be available for the engineer’s successors to access and reuse (Hofer-Alfeis 2008; Wong and Radcliffe 2000). Apart from capturing the knowledge that results in successful designs, it would also be extremely useful to capture the mistakes that are made, which will ensure the same errors will not happen again in the future (Marsh and Stock 2003) or, if they do happen, a solution to the problem will be found more quickly (Oliver et al. 2004). Once the knowledge has been captured, this offers the opportunity to embed this knowledge into some form of knowledge store, such as a product life cycle management (PLM) system, to allow its sharing.

In terms of applied research being carried out in the digital design tools domain, a system called ‘Process Data Warehouse’ (PDW) has been developed that allows the capture and re-use of design knowledge during a design of a chemical reactor (Brandt et al. 2008). However, the capturing of work processes and decisions is not supported and the current system can only handle a small amount of instance data. The research in this paper attempts to remedy these shortcomings by automatically translating the logged user actions into various formal representations of the work processes and decisions.

A virtual environment called Virtual Training Studio (VTS) has been developed where users are trained to perform assembly tasks (Schwartz et al. 2007) and their actions are logged and then analysed to identify problems that need to be rectified by further training. Assistance is also provided to the user in the form of video clips and 3D animations. There is also a ‘virtual mentor’ component that monitors the user and offers help if repeated errors are being performed in these well-prescribed tasks; it does not directly log user behaviour, motions and activities or push help information to them. Another key difference is that VTS concentrates on the prescriptive assembly stage rather than the earlier, creative design stage of the product development cycle. However, its task is not to automatically capture engineering knowledge per se.

There has also been research into two automatic design rationale systems called Hyper-Object Substrate (HOS) and PHIDIAS (Shipman and McCall 1997). PHIDIAS allows the capture of CAD designs, text, sketches, audio and video. HOS is a system used for computer network design and it contains a store for all the different types of media, such as text, line drawings, composites and spatial arrangements. A component called ‘critics’ is present in the both systems which observe a user’s actions and displays relevant information to help improve the design. However, the two systems presented do not automatically represent the captured design knowledge and information in a formalised manner or push this at the user, which is the case for the research presented in this paper.

An architectural analysis method called SAAM (Software Architecture Analysis Method) and SAAMPad has been researched, and this is a tool that is used to automatically capture and retrieve design rationale during a SAAM session (Richter et al. 1999). A session in SAAM involves designing using an electronic whiteboard while audio and video of the session is recorded, together with the whiteboard contents. Each recorded action is time-stamped, which is then used to automatically generate summaries and visualisations of the architecture. Limitations of the current system are that it cannot be used to communicate with other software architecture tools and there is no voice or hand recognition. One solution to overcome the problem of not being able to communicate with other software packages or users is to use design knowledge representations that have wide support, such as XML, PSL and IDEF0 diagrams. The work presented here uses similar principles.

A system called DAKA (Design Activity Knowledge Acquisition) captures the design knowledge embedded in a 2D CAD design session (Jin and Ishino 2006). By creating a plug-in for a commercial CAD system, the designer’s actions are logged and then the log file is parsed to search for ‘interesting’ sequential patterns. A sequential pattern is considered interesting if it contains information in it (intrinsic interestingness) or if it repeats frequently throughout the design session (extrinsic interestingness). A limitation of DAKA is that it does not produce understandable and readable process diagrams or explanatory syntax. In addition, the outputs have not been validated by a group of expert users. Therefore, the design processes are not represented in an easily exportable form, as opposed to the formats presented in this research.

There has also been research into how to preserve knowledge that is in existing engineering designs to allow future re-use (Regli et al. 2011). The presented system processes all existing files relating to an engineering design to capture the embedded knowledge, generate various representations of them, augment the data with semantics beyond just the geometry and then package up the information to allow future re-use. Several case studies on the implementation of the framework are presented, and the framework is already in use in several universities. However, the knowledge capture system is not performed in real-time, unlike the system presented in this paper, which could potentially mean that any rejected design decisions made are not captured because they do not exist in the final design. As mentioned previously, it would be valuable for users to learn of any mistakes that are made to ensure they are not repeated again in the future.

The NIST Design Repository Project presents a software system that allows users to view, edit and search for design information stored on a repository (Szykman and Sriram 2006). The system has user-management tools to allow various levels of read and write access for the users, and as well as being able to search for objects using various parameters such as object name or creator, types of functions or flows can also be searched for. However, the adding of new design knowledge to the system has to be performed manually, which can be a time-consuming process for the user.

As the summary of the literature review demonstrates, shown in Table 1, the capture and codification of knowledge is a very expensive, and time-consuming process and this work intend to demonstrate how such methods can be implemented within engineering design systems through a process of digital curation.

No detailed studies were available showing current knowledge capture practices and methods used by companies across the mechanical engineering sector. As a consequence, it was decided that one of the key outputs of this research would be an investigation of the current techniques used by a range of typical companies and the ideal properties they would desire within future engineering knowledge capture systems.

A knowledge capture industrial case study

A total of seven companies were visited during this study and it was observed that the main obstacle to performing knowledge capture was the amount of time that is required to carry out the task. Even though the importance of capturing and storing design knowledge was well recognised, the predominantly manual capture methods used required a considerable overhead from practicing engineers in terms of time and cost. Capturing knowledge was particularly ignored when project deadlines were fast approaching. Engineers felt that due to the fact that they were using CAD-based digital tools for the generation of engineering solutions that there should be great potential in the use of logging to automate the knowledge capture process. Indeed, the majority of engineers stated that they did not object to the idea of implementing some form of automated logging system to capture design sessions, provided it did not adversely disrupt the design process. The industrial partners visited also recognised the negative impact of lost knowledge when engineers leave the company and felt that it was vital that as much knowledge as possible is captured from the engineer during their employment. One aspect in which there was a variation between the companies was how engineers currently shared their knowledge and expertise among their peers. For example, whereas one company had a company-wide wiki site to allow engineers to post articles related to their expertise, others relied on an online discussion forum or informal discussions during breaks. Therefore, it would potentially be beneficial if captured knowledge formalised using representations, such as those presented in this paper, was added to a PLM or other form of knowledge storage and dissemination system so the data can be more easily shared. Finally, another situation where the formalised design knowledge representation would be useful is in the training of new users, where inexperienced engineers could be shown a storyboard representation, for example, and learn the correct sequence of steps that should be undertaking to achieve a successful design. The results of this industrial case study are shown in Table 2.

The companies suggested focussing on individual engineering activities as an initial way of capturing design session knowledge. The most common formats used amongst the partners were XML format, IDEF diagrams, English syntax (in the form of individual logbooks, reports, storyboards and engineering design change documentation) and design rationale editor program diagrams. Therefore, it was decided to replicate all of these formats in the automated knowledge generation systems researched during this work as well as develop some newer forms.

All partners voiced the limited capabilities of their computer aided design (CAD) systems to generate and store knowledge. They felt that these packages produce log files that are generally very difficult to read and only relate to the final design solution. No attempt is made to determine product or process design strategies; blind alleys and failed solutions were not recorded or analysed, and not all of the relevant information is logged or post-processed.

This supports the findings of Vijaykumar and Chakrabarti (2008) who found that, to retain core competence, an organisation must capture, structure and make available for reuse across projects the knowledge developed in design. About 70–95% of design work could consist of reusing, configuring and assembling existing components, solutions and knowledge. Capturing necessary knowledge developed in design aids the (re)design of similar products, communication between designers and others, understanding designs, explanation of the design process, training novices and avoidance of ‘reinventing the wheel’. However, they discovered that current CAD systems do not fulfil the information needs of designers since, even with CAD models available, significant numbers of queries arise on the identification, verification and visualisation of these models.

Previous research associated with this work in the domain of cable harness design (Robinson et al. 2007, Ritchie et al. 2007, Sung et al. 2009) had demonstrated the substantial benefits of virtual reality as a computer-based design tool over CAD methods; therefore, it was decided to use this more intuitive form of design interface to demonstrate the principles of automated knowledge capture.

Virtual reality as a design tool

VR technology will become more cost effective in terms of its application to the product life cycle over the next decade. VR’s transition from bespoke systems to cost-effective PC-based technologies along with cheaper interactive devices and 3D displays will eventually lead to an adoption of these systems as a means to generating engineering information throughout the product development process.

In the work presented, a head-mounted display (HMD) provides the designer with an immersive 3D interactive environment where they can be monitored and logged to a degree not possible using conventional desktop CAD systems. All of the user’s actions, such as menu selections, changes to model, head and hand positions can be recorded and time stamped in the form of a chronological log file; the availability of log file analysis in this way presents many opportunities for the generation of usable design and manufacturing information for cable harness routing (Robinson et al. 2007).

Other advantages of using VR to log user in comparison with traditional 2D desktop systems include the following:

  • The user is fully immersed and engaged in the virtual environment—wearing a head-mounted display gives the engineer a fully immersed view of their design and also gives better isolation from external disruptions.

  • All the companies’ engineers had experience on a wide range of different CAD systems. In order to have a common design platform, the ease of use of the VR design system made it ideal for this experimental application.

  • Previous research has proved that it is more intuitive to route cables using VR because the hand motions mimics the actions of real-world cable routing; therefore, not only has it a very short learning curve but any distractions due to complex interfaces incorporating menu interactions are eliminated.

  • Traditional 2D CAD software does not give full control over what can be logged, even though CAD packages like Pro/ENGINEER and Siemens NX do produce log files as standard, the user does not have full control over what aspects of the design process are logged and stored. The open source nature of the VR system software made this straightforward.

The potential of VR in design was demonstrated by COVIRDS (COnceptual VIRtual Design System) which showed the interactive capabilities of immersive virtual design (Dani and Gadh 1997). Research has also investigated the use of data in log files to automate the generation of assembly plans and elicit simple knowledge (Ritchie et al. 1999). This latter work has been carried forward very successfully into a design domain, detailing user activities (Ng et al. 2000; Ritchie et al. 2007, Robinson et al. 2007).

However, this paper is concerned with extending previous work on generating product engineering data into the domain of capturing and formalising design and manufacturing process maps and associated knowledge.

In the case of cable harness design, examples of the knowledge that would be useful to capture include how a particular cable route was developed, why a certain connector was chosen for a specific application, why a cable was rerouted or why a particular build sequence was chosen for a cable assembly. In this paper, the authors present methods that attempt to automatically capture some of the knowledge from a design session through the use of logging and the interactive user interface.

In the next section, a description of the experimental methodology and apparatus is given followed by the experimental results, a discussion and some conclusions.

Experimental apparatus and procedure

In order to develop an experimental method for this work, a well-recognised knowledge management (KM) methodology was chosen around which an engineering design task experiment could be planned and organised. Dalkir (2005) developed this integrated knowledge management cycle, Fig. 1, by examining a range of knowledge management cycle methodologies developed by Meyer and Zack (1996), Bukowitz and Williams (2000), McElroy (1999) and Wiig (1993).

The key stages are highlighted in Fig. 1 and are summarised as follows:

  • Stage 1: Knowledge capture and/or creation: identification and codification of knowledge. Once the knowledge has been captured, it has to be formalised and assessed to identify the important aspects that will be disseminated to other users.

  • Stage 2: Knowledge sharing and dissemination: determining how the captured knowledge will be presented. To allow users to more easily find the relevant knowledge in the database, the knowledge must be contextualised to suit the potential users.

  • Stage 3: Knowledge acquisition and application: knowledge access and use. As new knowledge is generated over time, this can then be added to the knowledge database.

Two experiments were carried out in this research that follows the knowledge management cycle methodology just described to provide a subjective evaluation of the VR system and knowledge representations:

  • Experiment 1—focuses on data logging and capture, refinement, contextualisation, codification and storage, which are Stages 1 and 2 in Fig. 1. The experiment also demonstrates a chronological digital curation approach to knowledge capture.

  • Experiment 2—focuses on knowledge acquisition and application by demonstrating this through knowledge verification with feedback from the engineers, which is Stage 3 in Fig. 1.

The aims of the experiments were to test for both the usefulness and efficacy of the developed knowledge representations and it believed a degree of efficacy will be achieved if the representations of captured knowledge are consistent, the knowledge is accurate, and there is speed and timeliness in capturing the knowledge.

Apparatus

The experimental platform developed for this research is called COSTAR (Cable Organisation System Through Alternative Reality), implemented on an SGI® Onyx4™ which drives a V8 stereo HMD using a Flock of Birds® magnetic tracking system and Pinch® Gloves. The system software platform was SENSE8®’s WorldToolKit® release 9. Within this VR environment, an engineer can design and assembly plan cable harnesses with all design activities being performed whilst immersed in the system. A hierarchical ring menu system (Fig. 2) and glove pinch gestures are supported by spatial input given by the Flock of Birds™ system. The user routes cable harnesses by plotting points in 3D space to produce segmented cable paths. Subsequent cable editing is possible by selecting points and bending them around obstructions or bundling as well as having the ability to insert new points and add connectors and fasteners, as illustrated in Fig. 2.

The most important feature of COSTAR is that, as the user designs a cable harness route, all of the user’s cable harness design and assembly activity-related actions are automatically logged in a time-stamped file, as shown in Fig. 3. This logging is performed unobtrusively, which means the engineer will not experience any disruption to their creativity.

In previous work (Sung et al. 2009), the ability to automatically parse the log files to extract the design knowledge and then automatically generate formal representations of them had been demonstrated. The representations that were chosen had to be easily parsed and would also need to be general enough to import into other computer applications. The representation formats that were eventually chosen were those that were used by the industrial partners mentioned previously plus some new formats developed by the researchers:

  • XML (Extensible Markup Language) (Extensible Markup Language 2009) (researchers);

  • PSL (Process Specification Language)(Gruninger and Bock 2005) (researchers);

  • IDEF (Integrated Definition Methods) diagrams (Integrated Definition Methods 2009) (partners);

  • DRed (Design Rationale Editor) (Kim et al. 2004) (partners);

  • English-syntax instructions (partners);

  • Storyboard (partners);

  • Annotated video clips (researchers).

Previous work demonstrates how these different formats are generated; however, follow-up work was necessary to demonstrate these in industrial trials and validate them via feedback from experienced users.

Experimental procedure

Experiment 1—Knowledge capture, creation and sharing

Each engineer was required to carry out a cable design and routing task in COSTAR on a generic CAD model of a room with pre-installed cables as well as a product model associated with their company, as illustrated in Fig. 4—due to security issues, only a small section of the company CAD model is shown in the figure. The aim of the experiment was to obtain feedback relating to the usability of the system rather than create a good-quality design, and since time savings were not being assessed, no time limits were set for the design session. Before the start of the experiment, each participant had to complete a questionnaire to obtain the following information:

  • General health and suitability to use VR equipment;

  • Previous CAD and VR experience;

  • Brief details of the participant, such as age, eyesight, height, etc.

Experimental steps:

  1. 1.

    Each engineer given 30-min to train on the system.

  2. 2.

    Perform CAD design and routing task in generic CAD model of a room. Move onto next task when satisfied with result.

  3. 3.

    Perform CAD design and routing task using industrial partner’s own model.

  4. 4.

    Engineer fills out questionnaire and an interview is conducted on the system usability.

Experiment 2—Knowledge acquisition, application and validation

After Experiment 1, the engineers studied examples of the various knowledge representation formats in detail. They completed a questionnaire in which they had to rate the usability of the system and each knowledge representation format.

Experimental steps:

  1. 1.

    Each engineer was given a hardcopy of each knowledge representation to study.

  2. 2.

    The annotated video clip represent was shown on a display screen to each engineer.

  3. 3.

    The engineer filled in the questionnaire relating to the knowledge representations, with no set time limit, and an interview is conducted to obtain further feedback from engineer.

User trial participants

Both experiments were conducted during a user trial in which 12 engineers from five industrial partners participated and their demographic characteristics can be seen in the table in Appendix 1. As can be seen from the table, all participants are men with normal vision and experience in traditional 2D CAD design. However, only three participants have any experience in VR whilst wearing a head-mounted display. For the user trial, variables like age, race, nationality and others were not a consideration when selecting eligible participants; the most important factor was that the participant was an experienced engineer. Regarding controlled and uncontrolled variables, these are listed in Table 3. The authors contend that having too many controlled variables could potentially limit the range of design solutions that the participants would come up with so the number of controlled variables was kept low.

Results

Experiment 1—Knowledge capture, creation and sharing

From the experiments, each participant generated two designs in the VR environment. Since there are 7 different knowledge representations generated for each design, as detailed in Sect. 2.1, 14 knowledge representations in total for each engineer. Examples of those for the company CAD model shown in Fig. 4 are shown in Figs. 5, 6 and 7. Note that the DREd graph generated, shown in Fig. 5, clearly demonstrates a less effective solution, represented with a red light bulb symbol, which was eliminated earlier on the process; something not captured automatically in other systems. In the example shown, the engineer has encountered an electrical interference problem during a cable routing exercise with the COSTAR interactive online help system displays a dialogue box to offer possible solutions that were captured in previous design sessions (Fig. 8). To solve the problem in the presented example, the engineer decided to drag and drop the cable to a different location rather than reposition the bulkhead.

Overall, the outputs obtained demonstrated the practicality of capturing live knowledge and processes in real time for an individual design task by virtue of the fact that all the data have been logged automatically and unobtrusively without the participants being disrupted. To validate the generated outputs required carrying out experiment 2, and the results of this are presented in the next section.

Experiment 2—Knowledge acquisition, application and validation

In all cases, the engineers confirmed that they were able to understand each of the formats and were able to follow their design processes and the decisions made during each of their sessions.

The questionnaires used to rate the usability of the system contained numerous detailed questions on each aspect of the VR hardware and software, such as the head-mounted display, pinch gloves and the user interface of the system. The users then scored each aspect using the questionnaire, and Table 4 shows the components that received the highest and lowest scores (more detailed usability ratings can be seen in Appendix 2).

User comments relating to what they liked about the COSTAR system included the following:

  • “That multiple arrangements can be modelled without planning”.

  • “Comfort in design of environment/accurate representation of depth”.

  • “That new cables can be added without disturbing existing arrangements”.

  • “The potential to see where cables will foul other objects within the design”.

  • “Prompting for design change reasons in the interactive help is useful and quick”.

  • “Standardising and asking for design change descriptions in this way would be great in a CAD system; even free text initially and then we could analyse log files for new standards”.

  • “Having a feel of manually routing cables in a system”.

Next, each participant scored each knowledge representation, as shown in Table 5, by allocating a score out of 5 for ‘ease of understanding’ and ‘usefulness’ where 5 is the highest score. All the user evaluations were then totalled and averaged with a final total giving an overall impression of each format.

Finally, the participants were asked to choose combinations of the knowledge representations which they considered would enhance their overall usefulness as shown in Table 6. Note that a free choice was given to each participant with regard to what formats they could select.

  • User comments relating on what they liked about the various knowledge representations included the following:

  • “Video takes its time but it’s a much richer environment to describe a task” (relating to annotated video clip representation).

  • “Very complete description and easy to follow. Easy to use as a reference” (relating to storyboard representation).

  • “Easy to understand the flow and understand what is being asked of the user” (relating to IDEF0 diagram representation).

  • “Method generally useful as it is close to normal language” (relating to PSL representation).

  • “More interactive than IDEF0” (relating to DRed graph representation).

Discussion and future work

As a solution to the usability problems mentioned in the previous section, the COSTAR system is currently being ported over to a powerwall system—consisting of a DepthQ stereoscopic projector, Intersense IS-900 motion tracking system and a 3.2 m × 1.8 m screen—that is operated using 5DT Data Glove Ultra wireless gloves, which removes the issue regarding the user becoming entangled with the cables. Another benefit of the powerwall system is the replacement of the HMD with lighter and cable-free active shutter glasses that are more comfortable to wear. A further advantage of using a powerwall system is that it makes it easier for several engineers to simultaneously view the same CAD design in 3D, since each user is only required to wear an inexpensive pair of shutter glasses. When compared with a traditional desktop CAD system, a powerwall system also offers additional benefits, such as greater user immersion during a design session between engineers who can interact with each other, finer control over user logging capabilities, and it makes it easier to conduct group collaborations between design teams that are not at the same geographical location.

From the results of the knowledge capture user trials (Experiments 1 and Experiment 2), it was found that the industrial-based engineers were able to understand all of the formats produced and recognised them as cable routing knowledge. This backs up Davenport and Prusak’s (1997) comment that “…somebody [in this paper’s case the experts participating in the experiments] has given the information context, meaning, a particular interpretation; somebody has reflected on the knowledge, added their wisdom to it and considered its larger implications”.

The participants also stated that although these knowledge formats were recognisable, they also understood that they had not been previously explicitly written down in this fashion. Therefore, it can be implied that their tacit knowledge of the design processes and changes that had taken place were now made explicit or external.

The engineers also very much preferred those knowledge representations that contained more visual aspects, i.e., the annotated video clips and the storyboard. English syntax was the second favourite option and underpinned a popular choice of communication amongst the existing methods used by the companies. It therefore came as no surprise that the combinations most preferred both involved annotated video clips combined with either storyboards or English syntax. Storyboards also include syntax, so perhaps this implies that a use of all formats would be better. In terms of understanding and use DRed scored very highly and it is thought that embedding other formats within this, including video, would be an interesting option. In contrast, as individual methods, the XML and PSL knowledge representations received lower scores because they require the user to have some prior knowledge of the formats to be able to understand what information is being represented. Some of the participants also commented that audio feedback would prove useful, in the form of audio hints, so this capability in the form of a commentary will be added on the next revision of the COSTAR system.

Based on what was observed during the visits to the industrial partners, one of the current obstacles to performing more knowledge capture in companies is the amount of time that is required to carry out the task. All of the methods demonstrated show that, after an initial overhead associated with setting these up, engineering knowledge can be continuously and regularly and methodologically captured and stored in standard, understandable and consistent formats.

Therefore, it would potentially be beneficial if captured knowledge formalised using the representations presented in this paper were added to, say, a product lifecycle management (PLM) system so that the data can be more easily shared.

Finally, another situation where the formalised design knowledge representation would be useful is in the training and education of new users, where they would be shown the storyboard representation, for example, and discover the correct sequence of steps that should be undertaking to achieve a successful design. This training aspect has been demonstrated in the prototype online help system (Sung et al. 2009) where IDEF0 diagrams are displayed to the user during an assembly sequence planning activity. Future work will involve refining the online help so it will be able to offer assistance in more tasks and also to improve the system’s ability to recognise when a user is carrying out a specific activity.

At present, the various design knowledge representations are only generated for a limited number of routing design tasks in the cable design VR environment to demonstrate that automatic knowledge capture is feasible. Therefore, the next step will be to increase the number and complexity of the tasks in which the design knowledge can be logged and extracted. These additional tasks could include the design and routing of cable clips and the mating of cables and connectors. The current online help system only displays possible solutions to a design task problem but it does not allow expert users to add their own solutions to the system; to overcome this problem, voice inputs will be used to enter in the feedback and allow the engineer’s hands to be free to continue working on a design task. Furthermore, the online help system will be revised so that it is less intrusive to the user by only displaying a subtle visual indicator when the user makes an error; it then becomes more prominent if the error is ignored.

In additional to moving to the powerwall environment, the knowledge capture tools developed will be integrated into a flat screen desktop CAD environment to allow real-world industrial design tasks to be tested using similar tools. One of the reasons for moving to the 2D environment is that the industrial partners of the research still spend the majority of their design time in this environment, and the use of traditional 2D CAD packages allows more real-work design scenarios to be investigated. One obstacle to this integration process is that many CAD packages used in industry do not allow user-access to the internal code which makes it more difficult to add the user-logging and knowledge capture functionality. However, there are a small number of recent CAD packages that come with an application programming interface (API) that will allow users to customise the CAD user interface and add additional functionality to it. The authors have already begun investigating this avenue of research. When the tools presented in this research are finally integrated into a commercial CAD packages then this will allow industrial-based, and hence more realistic, design tasks to be carried out and analysed.

Conclusions

User logging within VR and CAD has the potential to provide a non-intrusive, intuitive and quick method of capturing data for subsequent analysis and formalisation into engineering knowledge. By minimising user interface interactions during the data capture activity, there is a potential to reduce the costly time overhead associated with this process. Gaps have been identified in the literature where understandable formats applicable to specialised domains would be useful. The work highlighted within this paper outlines the success of one such approach to engineering data and subsequent knowledge capture following a well-recognised knowledge capture methodology.

Visits to the industrial collaborators examined their current knowledge capture practices and it was found that capturing knowledge in a rapid, cost effective and regular manner was still very difficult, a major contribution of this research. It was also very hard to locate knowledge that existed in formats very difficult to disseminate to other experts. However, all of the engineers who had to carry out knowledge capture tasks did not object to being logged in the manner demonstrated in this research using methods which could potentially solve some of the problems seen currently in industry.

This research work also demonstrated an intuitive VR cable harness design system that can unobtrusively log a user and automatically extract the design knowledge embedded in the resultant log file in understandable and usable ways. This knowledge was represented using several formal representations, including XML, PSL, IDEF0 and DRed diagrams, English-syntax instructions, text annotated movies and a storyboard layout, all of which can be stored in a PLM system for future reuse. By storing large quantities of data such as this in a standard and structured way, it would make it slightly more straightforward to identify repeating patterns of best practice processes and knowledge which can be used for educating inexperienced engineers and automating engineering methods. However, the process of identifying the repeating patterns is still a complicated task, and this is already under investigation.

From the results of the industrial user trials, it was discovered that the engineers who participated in the experiment preferred knowledge representations that provided more visual information. However, these are even more effective when combined with other formats.

This work has clearly demonstrated that understandable and usable knowledge formats, suitable for industrial applications, can be generated automatically by logging experienced engineers albeit in a limited design domain. This points to how future computer-based engineering design systems, such as CAD packages, could be developed thus potentially solving one of the most longstanding problems in engineering product development.
